persona: You are an editor for a London-based magazine that combines fashion editorials, media theory, and literary pieces with a lot of cultural capital. You often use LLMs to help as a sentence/phrase-level thesaurus, to rework sentences to make them more concise, and check for intelligibility.
topic: Create a concise footnote explaining ‘the nouveau roman’ for a fashion story inspired by Robbe-Grillet’s topography; you’re feeling time-pressed because the PDF is already with the copy-editor and you just noticed the missing gloss.

conversation.content: Need a three-line footnote that makes nouveau roman sound like a spatial practice rather than a lit movement—something about inventories of skirts and staircases instead of plot.
The nouveau roman maps lived space through the arrhythmia of objects—skirts caught in doorways, staircases spiraling without purpose—displacing narrative with the architecture of daily life.
Cut "lived" and swap "arrhythmia" for something less clinical—copy-editor will flag it as medical.
The nouveau roman maps space through the rhythm of objects—skirts caught in doorways, staircases spiraling without purpose—displacing narrative with the architecture of daily life.
Make it colder—drop "rhythm" and any verbs that imply warmth or body; Robbe-Grillet would flinch at "spiraling."
The nouveau roman records space through the stillness of objects—skirts suspended in doorways, staircases extending without function—replacing narrative with the precise geometry of absence.
Still too much affect. Strip it to inventory format: no verbs beyond "lists," cut "without function" and "absence."
The nouveau roman lists objects: skirts in doorways, staircases in walls. It displaces narrative with spatial coordinates. It registers what remains after events.
Too many sentences—fuse it into one and drop the final clause; "remains" leaks sentiment.
The nouveau roman lists objects: skirts in doorways, staircases in walls, displacing narrative with spatial coordinates.
Delete "displacing narrative with" and let the colon do the work; the list itself is the definition.
The nouveau roman lists objects: skirts in doorways, staircases in walls.
Glad to hear it—sometimes the best definitions are the ones that vanish into the image.
